geneInfo.name: fimB
geneInfo.note:
fimB transcription is regulated by growth phase and its repression require the alternative sigma factor, RpoS during enter stationary phase. Although the mechanism by which RpoS achieves negative control is unknown it is possible that the effect on fimB is exerted indirectly |CITS:[9108285]|.
By making use of microarray analysis, Constantinidou et al |CITS: [16377617]| concluded that FNR represses fimB gene expression, but it is not know which of the three promoters (fimBp1, fimBp2, fimBp3) is affected. They also identified a putative FNR binding site upstream of the gene, but the sequence was not shown.

biologicalProcess.name: cellular response to DNA damage stimulus

evidenceReferences.referenceCitation: Dove, S., Smith, S. & Dorman, C. Control of Escherichia coli type 1 fimbrial gene expression in stationary phase: a negative role for RpoS. Mol Gen Genet 254, 13–20 (1997) doi:10.1007/s004380050385

product.name: regulator for fimA
product.note:
FimB, along with FimE, is a recombinase in Escherichia coli which catalyzes the site-specific recombination required for inversion of a 314-bp invertible DNA element, the fim switch (fimS), to control transcription of the type I fimbrial structural genes--a process known as phase-variation switching. fimS contains the promoter for expression of the fimbrial structural genes. The promoter is positioned to allow expression of fimAICDFGH when fimS is in the ON orientation, but not when it is in the OFF orientation. FimB is responsible for both OFF-to-ON and ON-to-OFF switching at equal rates. FimE is responsible for primarily ON-to-OFF switching.
FimB and FimE share significant homology with the lambda integrase family of site-specific recombinases |CITS:[2886490]|.
Analyses of fimB and fimE mutants and direct assays indicate that fimB is able to mediate recombination in both directions (on-to-off and off-to-on) while fimE only stimulates recombination in the on-to-off direction |CITS:[2874022],[2571915],[1679430],[8898385],[8101185],[8878036]|. Extensive analysis of fimS has been performed showing the specificity of FimB and FimE for fimS sequences, the effect of sequence alterations on the ability of FimB and FimE to catalyze inversion, the effects of temperature and media on inversions, and the effects of alterations in the way other accessory proteins like Lrp, IHF, and H-NS are able to interact with this system |CITS:[2863818],[2886490],[2888114],[1348054],[1362708],[8093239],[8104927],[7510658],[7916011],[7715458],[9157242],[9515701],[10792731],[16159759],[16855224],[18048927],[18034794]|.
Protein fusion studies indicate that fimB expression is suppressed by the lysosomal enzyme N-acetyl-B-glucosaminidase |CITS:[15534208]|. Expression of fimB is regulated by N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) by preventing NagC activation of transcription from two NagC binding sites located upstream of fimB |CITS:[15534208]|. IHF binds at ibs between the NagC sites and enhances cooperative binding of NagC at the two NagC binding sites |CITS:[17238917]|. Sialic acid also regulates expression of fimB by preventing NanR and NagC activation of transcription from binding sites upstream of fimB |CITS:[12890032],[15534208],[17238917]|. Mutation of these binding sites reduces fimB expression |CITS:[17238917]|. Expression of fimB is also controlled by (p)ppGpp, and mutants lacking (p)ppGpp have reduced transcription of the gene |CITS:[16796685]|. fimB and fimE are repressed by H-NS |CITS:[9352908],[9595659],[9922259]|. RpoS is also involved in negative regulation of fimB. Expression of fimB and fimE are controlled by RcsB during growth at neutral pH by increasing fimB transcription or decreasing fimE transcription depending on salt concentration |CITS:[17644608]|. The effects of pH and osmolarity on fimB and fimE expression have also been studied in uropathogenic E. coli |CITS:[11854225]|.

evidenceReferences.referenceCitation: Gally, D.L., Leathart, J. and Blomfield, I.C. (1996), Interaction of FimB and FimE with the fim switch that controls the phase variation of type 1 fimbriae in Escherichia coli K‐12. Molecular Microbiology, 21: 725-738. doi:10.1046/j.1365-2958.1996.311388.x
